question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
The number
\[\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ\]is expressed in the form $r \, \text{cis } \theta$, where $r > 0$ and $0^\circ \le \theta < 360^\circ$.  Find $\theta$ in degrees.
inference:
The given sum is
\[\sum_{k=0}^7 \text{cis} (75^\circ + 8^\circ k) = \sum_{k=0}^7 \text{cis} (75^\circ + 8^\circ k) = \sum_{k=0}^7 \left(\cos(75^\circ + 8k^\circ) + i \sin(75^\circ + 8k^\circ)\right)\]
We have a sum of the form $\sum_{k=0}^{n-1} \text{cis}(\alpha + k\beta)$, which can be expressed as
\[\sum_{k=0}^{n-1} (\cos(\alpha + k\beta) + i \sin(\alpha + k\beta))\]
The sum of complex numbers is a complex number.
By the formula for the sum of a geometric series, we have
\[\sum_{k=0}^7 \text{cis}(75^\circ + 8k^\circ) = \sum_{k=0}^7 \text{cis} (75^\circ) \text{cis} (8k^\circ) = \text{cis} 75^\circ \sum_{k=0}^7 \text{cis} (8k^\circ) = \text{cis} 75^\circ \left(\frac{\text{cis} (8\cdot 8^\circ) - 1}{\text{cis} 8^\circ - 1}\right)\]
\[= \text{cis} 75^\circ \left(\frac{\text{cis} 64^\circ - 1}{\text{cis} 8^\circ - 1}\right)\]
\[= \frac{\text{cis} 75^\circ (\text{cis} 64^\circ - 1)}{\text{cis} 8^\circ - 1} = \frac{e^{i\pi/24} (e^{i64 \pi/180} - 1)}{e^{i8 \pi/180} - 1}\]
Using the sum of cis terms formula,
\[\sum_{k=0}^{n-1} \text{cis} (a + k b) = \text{cis} a \frac{\text{cis} (nb) - 1}{\text{cis} b - 1}\]
We have
\[\sum_{k=0}^7 \text{cis} (75^\circ + 8k^\circ) = \text{cis} 75^\circ \frac{\text{cis} (7\cdot 8^\circ) - 1}{\text{cis} 8^\circ - 1} = \text{cis} 75^\circ \frac{\text{cis} 56^\circ - 1}{\text{cis} 8^\circ - 1}\]
In our case, $a=75^\circ$, $b=8^\circ$, $n=8$.
\[\text{cis } 75^\circ \frac{\text{cis} (7 \cdot 8^\circ) - 1}{\text{cis} 8^\circ - 1} = \text{cis} 75^\circ \frac{\text{cis} 56^\circ - 1}{\text{cis} 8^\circ - 1} = \text{cis} 75^\circ \frac{2i \sin(28^\circ)}{2i \sin 4^\circ} = \text{cis} 75^\circ \frac{\sin 28^\circ}{\sin 4^\circ}\]
The argument is $\theta = 75^\circ$.
Then we are dealing with $\theta = 75^\circ$, where $n=8, a = 75^\circ, b = 8^\circ$.
Final Answer: $\boxed{75}$
ground_truth:
First, we note that the angle measures form an arithmetic sequence whose average is $111^\circ$.

We have that
\begin{align*}
&\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ  \\
&= \frac{\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ}{\text{cis } 111^\circ} \cdot \text{cis } 111^\circ \\
&= [\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)] \text{cis } 111^\circ.
\end{align*}The terms of the sum
\[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]can be paired into terms of the form $\text{cis } n^\circ + \text{cis } (-n)^\circ$, and
\begin{align*}
\text{cis } n^\circ + \text{cis } (-n)^\circ &= \cos n^\circ + i \sin n^\circ + \cos n^\circ - i \sin n^\circ \\
&= 2 \cos n^\circ,
\end{align*}which is real.  Therefore,
\[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]is real.  Let
\[r = \text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ).\]Then
\[\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ = r \, \text{cis } 111^\circ,\]so $\theta = \boxed{111^\circ}$.

inference:
Using the formula for the sum of a geometric series of complex numbers,
$$\sum_{k=0}^{n-1} \text{cis}(\alpha + k\beta) = \text{cis}(\alpha) \frac{\text{cis}(n\beta) - 1}{\text{cis}(\beta) - 1}$$
In this case, $\alpha = 75^\circ$, $\beta = 8^\circ$, and $n = 8$.
So,
$$\sum_{k=0}^7 \text{cis}(75^\circ + 8k^\circ) = \text{cis}(75^\circ) \frac{\text{cis}(8 \times 8^\circ) - 1}{\text{cis}(8^\circ) - 1} = \text{cis}(75^\circ) \frac{\text{cis}(64^\circ) - 1}{\text{cis}(8^\circ) - 1}$$
Using the formula $ \text{cis}(x) - 1 = 2i \sin\left(\frac{x}{2}\right) e^{i x/2}$,
$$\sum_{k=0}^7 \text{cis}(75^\circ + 8k^\circ) = \text{cis}(75^\circ) \frac{2i\sin(32^\circ)}{2i\sin(4^\circ)} = \text{cis}(75^\circ) \frac{\sin(32^\circ)}{\sin(4^\circ)}$$
The magnitude of the term is $\frac{\sin(32^\circ)}{\sin(4^\circ)} = \frac{\sin(32^\circ)}{\sin(4^\circ)}$. This is a real number.
The argument of the complex number is $75^\circ$.
The given sum is
$$\sum_{k=0}^7 \text{cis}(75^\circ + 8k^\circ) = \sum_{k=0}^7 [\cos(75^\circ + 8k^\circ) + i \sin(75^\circ + 8k^\circ)]$$
Using the formula,
$$\sum_{k=0}^{n-1} \text{cis}(a+k b) = \text{cis}(a)\frac{\text{cis}(n b)-1}{\text{cis}(b)-1}$$
For $n=8, a=75^\circ, b=8^\circ$
$$ = \text{cis}(75^\circ) \frac{\text{cis}(8\times 8^\circ) - 1}{\text{cis}(8^\circ)-1} = \text{cis}(75^\circ) \frac{\text{cis}(64^\circ)-1}{\text{cis}(8^\circ)-1} = \text{cis}(75^\circ)\frac{2 i\sin(32^\circ)}{2i\sin(4^\circ)} = \text{cis}(75^\circ)\frac{\sin(32^\circ)}{\sin(4^\circ)}$$
$$ = \frac{\sin(32^\circ)}{\sin(4^\circ)} \text{cis}(75^\circ)$$
The modulus is $\frac{\sin(32^\circ)}{\sin(4^\circ)} = 7.98 \approx 8$.
The argument is $75^\circ$.
$75^\circ$.

Final Answer: $\boxed{75}$
ground_truth:
First, we note that the angle measures form an arithmetic sequence whose average is $111^\circ$.

We have that
\begin{align*}
&\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ  \\
&= \frac{\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ}{\text{cis } 111^\circ} \cdot \text{cis } 111^\circ \\
&= [\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)] \text{cis } 111^\circ.
\end{align*}The terms of the sum
\[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]can be paired into terms of the form $\text{cis } n^\circ + \text{cis } (-n)^\circ$, and
\begin{align*}
\text{cis } n^\circ + \text{cis } (-n)^\circ &= \cos n^\circ + i \sin n^\circ + \cos n^\circ - i \sin n^\circ \\
&= 2 \cos n^\circ,
\end{align*}which is real.  Therefore,
\[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]is real.  Let
\[r = \text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ).\]Then
\[\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ = r \, \text{cis } 111^\circ,\]so $\theta = \boxed{111^\circ}$.
